entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Write $\pi_{A,n}$ (resp.~$\pi_{I,n}$) for the steady state probability that $n$ ligands $L$ are bound and the receptor is in the active (resp.~inactive) state. Suppose up to $N$ ligands can be bound in total.

At equilibrium, a perturbation of the ligand concentration is equivalent to a linear combination of vertex perturbations:

and so \eqref{vertex} implies

where $\langle n\rangle _A$ (resp.~$\langle n \rangle_I$) is the average number of ligands bound when the receptor is in the active state. This provides a transparent derivation of a well-known result.

Now in fact, the decomposition in \eqref{ladder} should also include many edge function perturbations, but we ignore them above because we assume the system is at equilibrium.

Next we could try to determine what improvement in sensitivity is possible out of equilibrium—forgetting for now factors of $\tanh$ because even at $F \to \infty$ there is some bound. By the single-rate perturbation bound, I don’t think $[L] \frac{\partial \pi_A}{\partial [L]}$ can ever exceed $N/2$ (to be sure I need to think more carefully about the structure of the graph).

Polytope

Our desire to understand complicated out-of-equilibrium systems—such as living things—has led to intense interest in quantities, such as entropy production . Studying entropy production can lead to progress because although living things are complicated, they are often sustained by interactions with a simpler .

However, as emphasized by many authors, kinetics also play a key role in determining the properties of . In many examples,

A precise expression for the NESS distribution in terms of transitions rates is given by the matrix-tree . As a simple corollary of the matrix-tree theorem, it follows that .

These extreme states are states where there is no dissipation,

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.
